do.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: used with another verb to form questions or negatives
do.translation[0].definitions[0].example: I don’t feel like going out tonight.
do.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: used to form question tags (=short questions that you add to the end of statements)
do.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: used instead of repeating a verb that has already been used
do.translation[0].definitions[2].example: So now you know as much as I do.
‘You forgot all about it.’ ‘No, I didn’t.’
‘I want to go home.’ ‘So do I.’
I didn’t believe the story and neither did he.
do.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: used to emphasize the main verb in a sentence
do.translation[0].definitions[3].example: You do look nice in that hat.
I do think she’s behaved badly.
‘You should have warned me.’ ‘But I did warn you.’
He owns, or did own  (=emphasizing past tense), a yacht.
do.translation[0].definitions[4].definit: used when politely offering someone something
do.translation[1].definitions[0].definit: to perform an action or activity
do.translation[1].definitions[0].example: Have you done your homework yet?
You need to do more exercise.
It’s a pleasure doing business with you.
I didn’t know what to do.
All he does is sit in front of the television all day.
We should do something to help him.
It all happened so quickly that I couldn’t do anything about it.
bored teenagers with nothing to do
It’s your turn to do the dishes.
do.translation[1].definitions[0].note_bo: In written English, people often use the verb act rather than the phrase do something, as it sounds more formal:
The government needs to act to help these people.
do.translation[1].definitions[1].definit: used to ask or talk about how successful someone is at something
do.translation[1].definitions[1].example: Students are under considerable pressure to do well.
You should get promoted after about a year, depending on how you’re doing.
How’s he doing in trying to give up smoking?
do.translation[1].definitions[2].definit: to have a particular effect on something or someone
do.translation[1].definitions[2].example: The scandal will do serious damage to his reputation.
This will do nothing for (=will not improve) Jamie’s confidence.
The colour does nothing for her  (=does not improve her appearance).
Getting the job has done a lot for (=had a good effect on) her self-esteem.
A week in the countryside will do you good (=make you feel better).
Exercise can do wonders for (=have a very good effect on) body, mind, and spirit.
do.translation[1].definitions[3].example: What do you want to do after you leave school?
What do you do for a living (=as your job)?
She’s very good at what she does.
do.translation[1].definitions[4].definit: used to say that something will be enough or be acceptable
do.translation[1].definitions[4].example: We don’t have a lot of wine for the party, but it should just about do.
I can’t find my black shoes so these will have to do.
A few sandwiches will do me for lunch.
It won’t do (=it is not acceptable) to say that the situation couldn’t have been avoided.
do.translation[1].definitions[5].definit: to spend a period of time doing something
do.translation[1].definitions[5].example: She did a year backpacking around the world.
Oh yes, I certainly did my time in the army  (=spent time in the army).
do.translation[1].definitions[6].definit: to study a particular subject in a school or university
do.translation[1].definitions[6].example: I did French for five years.
do.translation[1].definitions[7].definit: to cook a particular type of food
do.translation[1].definitions[7].example: I was thinking of doing a casserole tonight.
do.translation[1].definitions[8].definit: to provide a particular service or sell a particular product
do.translation[1].definitions[8].example: They do interior and exterior design.
We don’t do food after two o'clock.
do.translation[1].definitions[9].definit: to perform a particular play, show etc
do.translation[1].definitions[9].example: We did ‘Guys and Dolls’ last year.
do.translation[1].definitions[10].defini: to paint or decorate a room, house etc
do.translation[1].definitions[10].exampl: How are you going to do your living room?
do.translation[1].definitions[11].defini: to behave in a particular way
do.translation[1].definitions[11].exampl: In the evenings students are free to do as they please (=do what they want).
I wish you’d do as you’re told (=do what you are told to do)!
do.translation[1].definitions[12].defini: to copy someone’s behaviour or the way they talk, especially in order to entertain people
do.translation[1].definitions[12].exampl: He does a brilliant George Bush  (=copies him in a very funny way).
do.translation[1].definitions[13].exampl: He says he’s never done hard drugs in his life.
do.translation[1].definitions[14].defini: to visit a particular place, especially as a tourist
do.translation[1].definitions[14].exampl: Let’s do the Eiffel Tower today.
do.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: to perform an action or activity
do.translation[1].note_box[0].sections[0: On Saturdays I usually do a few jobs around the house.
She was feeling too tired to do any work.
Who does the cooking in your family?
I’ve been doing the housework all day.
Will anyone help me do the washing-up?
My parents don’t let me go out unless I’ve done my homework.
I did a quick calculation on a piece of paper.
The company does a lot of business in China.
He lay on the sofa and did nothing all day.
do.translation[1].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 3: to have a particular effect on something or someone
do.translation[1].note_box[1].sections[0: It might do some good if you talk to him about the problem.
The fresh air has done me good.
not do (somebody) any harm also do (somebody) no harm
One or two chocolate cookies won’t do you any harm.
A mistake like that can do a lot of damage to your career.
do.translation[1].note_box[1].sections[1: The new leisure centre has done a lot for the town’s image.
Being apart for so long did nothing for our relationship.
I liked the dress but it did nothing for me.
A new haircut can do wonders for your self-confidence.
I followed his advice but it did more harm than good.
do.translation[1].note_box[2].sections[0: do
to do something – used in the following phrases
It usually takes me a couple of hours to do my homework.
She’s gone to the supermarket to do the shopping.
The doctor did some tests.
Fraser spent some time in Egypt doing some archaeological research.
Scientists are doing research on two types of vaccine.
Have you decided which course you want to do at university?
to do something – used in the following phrases
The prince made a short speech.
Can I make a suggestion?
The committee will meet to make their final decision.
I think someone has made a mistake.
to do something – used in the following phrases
They’ve asked him to give a talk.
The band gave a brilliant performance.
to do something – used in the following phrases
Kate’s taking her driving test tomorrow.
I think I’ll go and take a shower.
Normally, he took a walk in the evenings.
commit
to do something that is a crime, especially a serious crime
The crime was committed in the early hours of the morning.
Dixon later admitted committing the robbery.
carry out something
to do something – used in the following phrases
The violence is making it difficult for firefighters to carry out their work.
He still managed to carry out his duties.
The hospital carries out research into skin diseases.
The operation was carried out at a hospital in Paris.
They didn’t carry out their threat to kill the hostages.
I’m sure I can rely on you to carry out my instructions.
perform
to do something. Perform is more formal than carry out, and is used in the following phrases
The job mostly involves performing administrative tasks.
A team of surgeons performed the operation.
conduct
to do something – used in the following phrases
They conducted a survey of approximately 2,000 people living in the area.
The police are conducting an investigation into the cause of the fire.
Knowing how to conduct a successful interview is a skill.
People were unimpressed by the way in which the election campaign was conducted.
go about something
to do your work or the things that you usually do, especially when something serious has happened
The next day she went about her business as if nothing had happened.
get on with something
to start doing something that you should have started already or to continue doing something that you stopped doing for a short time
I need to get on with my homework.
be up to something
to be doing something that you think is probably bad, although you do not know exactly what it is
I’m sure they’re up to something.
What’s Jake up to? He’s been upstairs in his room all day.
do.translation[2].definitions[0].definit: a party or other social event
do.translation[2].definitions[0].example: We’re having a do to celebrate his 30th birthday.
